Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: Sustainable Rare Earth Element Recycling from Neodymium Magnets
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project will implement a proprietary rare earth extraction process on recycled NdFeB magnets at pilot scale to prove commercial production feasibility. By recovering rare earth elements (REEs) readily available in waste streams, this effort will help create a secondary source of these critical elements, thereby reducing U.S. dependence on an unstable, limited supply from China. This will, in turn, lay the groundwork necessary for the production of cutting-edge technologies reliant upon these materials to return to the U.S. The Nd and Dy elements which are recovered from this process are the critical components that increase the efficiency of electric motors by up to 30%. The availability of these resources will also significantly improve the vertical integration of manufacturing for national security technologies that depend heavily upon REEs, such as guided missile actuators and jet-fighter control panels. This project will also impact the electronics recycling sector by creating a new, reliable revenue stream for electronics recycling companies.

The process to reclaim REEs from NdFeB magnets is simple and energy-efficient, with a minimal environmental footprint. The Phase I SBIR project demonstrated the feasibility of developing the process beyond laboratory scale to pilot scale, improved the purity of the end product and reduced the amount of waste from processing. The Phase II project will focus on the following objectives: 1) designing a scale up strategy and building a pilot scale production plant; 2) optimizing the pilot scale production process; 3) maximizing product recovery at pilot scale; 4) designing a wastewater treatment and reuse strategy; and 5) minimizing residual contamination in the final products. To achieve these Phase II objectives, we will develop process parameters for maximum yield, maximum purity, and minimum processing times at pilot scale. The first stage will be to successfully obtain production yields of 90+% and purity levels of 99+% in pilot scale batches. For the second stage, we will focus on scaling production to prove commercial-scale feasibility, with ideal product yields and purities of 95+% and 99+% respectively. Throughout all stages, we will focus on understanding and treating the accompanying waste products, including wastewater and residual metal impurities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF Outcomes Report

Significant outcomes in three areas were the results of the Phase II-SBIR project.

Completion of the pilot facility

The major goal of this Phase II-SBIR project was to develop a pilot-scale production facility which lays the foundation for commercial scale use of Rare Resource Recycling’s (REEcycle’s) patented technology that reclaims the ‘magnetic’ rare earths (Nd-Pr, Dy) from permanent (NdFeB) magnets.

Because hydrogen is produced during the REEcycle process, the pilot plant is best suited for an outdoor site. The location selected was once used by Shell Oil Company for a pilot project. The site was proposed by Wingo, a Conroe TX based engineering and construction company experienced in executing greenfield projects. Wingo was an integral part of the pilot plant design and coordinated all phases of constructions.

The major equipment that was installed at the pilot facility consists of: 1) a 500-gallon, jacketed reactor; 2) a 20 gpm centrifuge; 3) a 1,500-liter liquid nitrogen tank; and 4) a 36-kw steam generator; (5) a cooling tower with a water recycling system; (6) and a compressor. This equipment will be used to produce our rare earth concentrate mixture from batch sizes of 25 kg-75 kg of prepared magnetic material. 

With the equipment specifications complete and orders placed the, installation began September 24, 2017. All of the equipment was tested, fired up, and processing started in late February, 2018.

Magnet acquisition and the disk disassembly machine

REEcycle recognizes the need to source magnets from multiple supply chains. Our two-pronged approach for this pilot phase was to secure NdFeB magnets from computer hard disk drives (HDDs) and to establish a source that recycled magnets from other than HDDs.

End-of-life computer hard disk drives (HDDs) are aggregated at electronics recyclers (ER) and also available in substantial numbers at data centers (DC). In both instances, the HDDs are shredded to assure data security but doing so complicates the recovery of valuable commodities and the precious NdFeB magnets. Until now, to reclaim the magnetic material would require removing the magnet sets from the HDDs by hand prior to shredding. This is a time consuming and labor-intensive process that yields 16 grams of magnetic material per HDD on average. It would require removing magnet sets from over 1500 drives by hand for each 25Kg batch and nearly 5000 HDDs for each 75kg batch process run at the pilot plant.

After multiple test tools and two prototypes, REEcycle has designed a disk drive disassembly machine (DDM 3.0) capable of processing HDDs at a rate of one every five seconds. During the disassembly process, the HDD is separated into its major components and sorted into assigned bins significantly increasing  value of the separated components. Components include the stainless-steel lid, the aluminum chassis, the magnet set, and the disk-motor assembly. The disk-motor assembly is further separated into the spindle/motor assembly and the disks. The disks are shredded to assure data destruction.

REEcycle will secure 50 metric tons of magnets from ERs in 2020 using DDM 3.0. 

After multiple attempts to purchase magnets from suppliers, both international and domestic, we located a source of magnets in Europe that has a stockpile of thirteen tonnes and a continuous supply of about four tonnes per year. REEcycle secured magnetic material from a second source in Europe during its laboratory experiments. US metals brokers have approached us with significant supplies of quality magnets. The process of locating magnet suppliers is ongoing.

 

Magnet preparation

Preparing magnets for the patented rare earth recovery process requires: 1) a commercial/industrial oven to demagnetize the NdFeB magnets and to separate the NdFeB magnets from their permalloy backing. 2) a mechanical removal of the Ni-Cu-Ni coating and 3) a size reduction process to correctly size the magnet particles for the chemical reaction.

The sizing proved to be more of a problem than anticipated. The grinding process creates dust that is a potential explosion hazard with the rapid oxidation of the rare earths posing a fire hazard. Slow oxidation of the stored prepared material reduces the percentage of rare earth concentrate recovered compared to the amount available. REEcycle has solved these problems and there is confidence these solutions will transfer to a commercial scale production process.

After a series of tests for both mechanical and electro-chemical removal of the Ni-Cu-Ni coating, the mechanical process proved to be the only feasible pathway. This approach also proved scalable for the outputs projected for the commercial process.

The oven demagnetization and permalloy separation will work at the pilot scale but will need to be reworked at the commercial scale.

The production amounts of rare earth concentrates anticipated at the time of the grant application were not met. The issues we ran into with magnet acquisition have been solved. The problems with magnet preparation have been solved or nearly solved.

 


Last Modified: 06/29/2019
Modified by: Casey Mcneil
